column1: Scheie syndrome is metabolism disease in which the body cannot properly break down long chains of sugar molecules called glycosaminoglycans (formerly called mucopolysaccharides).
Without the enzyme, glycosaminoglycans build up in body tissues and can damage organs, including the heart.

Symptoms may not appear until age 4 or 5, and may include: - Broad mouth with full lips - Claw hands and deformed feet - Cloudy cornea and progressive loss of vision, resulting in blindness - Coarsened facial features - Increased body hair - Jaws that extend out farther than normal - Stiff joints
